children.subject: If your % grade don't match the grade bins for the course, you should definitely consider emailing the staff for correction.

Thanks! I've been waiting for their response. However, this class is curved and there is not a specific grade bin line. I don't even know what's the threshold for A- but it is unlikely that it lies somewhere between 92.19 and 92.11 right?
so there really could be a difference as small as 0.08% away from next grade bin that is not considered as an equal grade?
I don't know how differentiating grades for curved classes works and I've always been curious but... I guess they must draw the line somewhere right? :(
unfortunately this is all the information about grading on syllabus : (. I don't see an explicit line between grades anywhere. Thanks for the help!

Percentage based grade bins are not standard across courses. Some courses curve on %, so just use a flat curve based on total points.

These are the only departmental guidelines:
https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/faculty-staff/academic-personnel/grading-guidelines-undergrad

I would, personally, ask in each course -- at the beginning, and the end of the semester-- how to interpret grades. The unfortunate reality is that there's always a cutoff somewhere. Many instructors do pay special attention to the boundaries, but no matter how careful, someone will always be just on one side. :( It does suck -- I've been there too, but know that overall you're doing well in your courses. :)
Would you share which CS class did you get a B+ on? Traditionally this shouldn't happen.

history.content:
Among the three CS classes I took this semester, I was 0.5% away from the next grade bin in one class but still couldn't get it; more disappointingly, in another class, I got 92.11% on bcourses but a B+ on CalCentral, while one of my classmates got 92.19% and she's a A-. I'm feeling extremely disappointed and unfair right now. This really ruined my whole semester's hard work, making me feel that my work was meaningless and really discourages me from working hard: if this is what students get out of their hard work, then why would they work hard in the first place?

Can anyone kindly give some advice or tips to get over this? I'm not sure wether I can stay as incentivized as before. Thank you very much.
history.subject: Looking for Advice on Interpreting Final Grades
